his envisaged challengers to define the sequence of “intermediates” for him.
Savvy champions of the concrete case argument know this story. They ap-
preciate Darwin’s ingenuity in responding to the challenge, and, although
they think the response ultimately fails, their reasons for this judgment de-
pend on a more general problem for evolution under natural selection. That
more general problem derives from the fine structure of the components o
